bibl.title: Letter from Wade H. Frost to Henry Rose Carter, March 21, 1922

div1.p: Frost comments on Carter's report on influenza and pneumonia in Panama and urges him to publish it. He feels Carter's lectures were the best they have had at Johns Hopkins.

div1.head: Letter from Wade H. Frost to Henry Rose Carter, March 21, 1922
div1.opener:
Miscel
Lectures
THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
SCHOOL OF HYGIENE AND PUBLIC HEALTH
310-312 WEST MONUMENT STREET
BALTIMORE, MD. March 21, 1922.
DEPARTMENT OF EPIDEMIOLOGY
Dr. Henry R. Carter,
2121 California Street, N.W.,
Washington, D.C.
My dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
I am returning, enclosed, your notes on the
efficacy of vaccination against yellow fever, which
answered my question as fully and precisely as questions
are always answered by you. I am very much obliged
to you for remembering and taking the trouble to send
me the notes.

Under separate cover I am returning to you
your copy of the Scientific Monthly containing the ar-
ticle “Adventures in Stupidity” which is most enter-
taining and I think instructive.

I am indebted to you again for your copy of
the report on pneumonia in Panama which I will return
to you later, after I have taken advantage of your per-
mission to have it copied. Three points in the report
are of very special interest to me, the association of
influenza with the pneumonia epidemic, the high prevalence
of pneumonia among the new-comers which corresponds
exactly to the experience reported by Opie, Freeman, et al
at Camp Funston and Camp Pike in 1918, and finally the
fact that the two periods of highest prevalence of
pneumonia in August-September, 1906 and March-April, 1907
are separated by an interval of approximately eight months,
which is very interesting and suggestive in connection
with Brownlee's observation upon the tendency of influ-
enza epidemics to recur at intervals or multiples of eight
months (33 weeks). It seems to me that we are accumulat-
ing considerable evidence (as you would say, “not proof”)
that epidemics of pneumonia are apt to be, perhaps always,
associated with epidemics of influenza, which may be un-
recognized or at least unreported. I wish you would pub-
lish your Panama report, or at least a note giving its
Dr. Carter
-2-
3-12-22
substance for I think the observations are of real value.

I cannot adequately thank you for your three lec-
tures which were a delight to all who heard them, and
which, with all due respect to other lecturers, were easily
the best lectures that we have had here. The check for
your small honorarium should be received within a week or
two. I am sorry that it will hardly more than pay your
traveling expenses, and hope that you will thinkunderstand that it
does not in any sense measure our appreciation of your
lectures.

With sincere regards to yourself and Miss Carter,
and hoping that we may see something of both of you in
the future,
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, W. H. Frost. WHF:G
